awd_abstract_narration:
The Inner Model Program is one of the central areas of Set Theory. The traditional view of this program has been that of an increment program with progress measured by a progression up the hierarchy of large cardinals. It is now known that this view is not correct. A critical transition occurs at the level of exactly one supercompact cardinal, and in solving the Inner Model Problem for this specific large cardinal axiom, one solves the Inner Model Problem for essentially all known large cardinal axioms. The solution must necessarily yield an ultimate enlargement of Godel's inner model L. This  Ultimate-L must closely approximate the parent universe V within which it is constructed. Though the detailed construction of Ultimate-L is open, the axiom, ``V = Ultimate-L'',  can be precisely formulated and its consequences explored even now. One can also precisely specify a conjecture which would be the final outcome of the construction of Ultimate-L. This is the Ultimate-L Conjecture. This conjecture is closely related to several other conjectures and these collectively are the focus of this research proposal.

The mathematical study of Infinity is the focus of Set Theory. This subject began on the basis of principles isolated by Cantor and then elaborated on by others. By the early part of the 20th century the basic Zermelo-Frankel Axioms had been isolated and these axioms together with the Axiom of Choice are the ZFC axioms. The ZFC axioms define the current conception of (mathematical) Infinity. The seminal discoveries of the latter half of the 20th century showed that most of the fundamental questions asked about infinite sets are unsolvable on the basis of the ZFC axioms. Famous among these unsolvable questions is that of Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis which by the middle of the 20th century was widely regarded as one of the most important questions of mathematics.  This proposal focuses on the Ultimate-L Project. This project if successful will isolate (for the first time) an extension of the ZFC axioms that will resolve essentially all of these otherwise unsolvable questions (including that of the Continuum Hypothesis) and provide a framework for reducing all questions of Set Theory to questions of the existence of large infinite sets--these are the so called Axioms of Strong Infinity.  The new approach arises from a series of recent results which show that such an extension of the ZFC axioms might actually exist.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Set Theory is that area of Mathematics whose focus is the formal study of Mathematical Infinity. The ZFC axioms, discovered and adopted in the early part of the 20th century, specify our initial conception ofthet Universe of Sets, which in Mathematics is now denoted by V. By the end of the 20th century, the exploration of the Universe of Sets on the basis of the ZFC axioms had revealed that most of the basic questions, such as that of Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis from 1878, cannot be answered on the basis of the ZFC axioms alone. Further it was also discovered that the primary source of new axioms, large cardinal axioms, could also not directly resolve this issue. This was all the result of Cohen's seminal discovery in 1963 of the method of forcing and the subsequent refinements of that method over the ensuing 50 years. The discovery and analysis of the hierarchy of large cardinal axioms, these are axioms which assert the existence of "very large" infinities, is one of the major developments in Set Theory during the latter half of the 20th century.

Goedel's attempts at resolving  Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis led to his discovery in 1939  of the axiom V = L, which asserts that every set is constructible. Remarkably this axiom does resolve essentially all the questions, such as Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis, which Cohen's method of forcing and its subsequent refinements show cannot be answered on the basis of the ZFC axioms alone.  However, Scott showed in 1960 that this axiom is refuted by large cardinal axioms and so must be rejected. The program to find generalizations of Goedel's axiom V= L which are compatible with large cardinal axioms, while very successful on a case by case basis, seemed by its very nature intrinsically unable find a single version of that axiom which is not refuted by any large cardinal axiom.

However, in a completely unexpected development, this strongly held intuition turned out not to be correct and so the search for the ultimate version of Goedel's axiom began. On the basis of research supported by series of previous grants, the PI formulated a candidate for exactly such an axiom, V = Ultimate L, by using ideas from yet another area of significant development in Set Theory over the last 50 years. This is the area of Descriptive Set Theory in the context of the Axiom of Determinacy.  Further the PI formulated a specific conjecture, the Ultimate L Conjecture, which if true verifies that this axiom, V = Ultimate L, cannot be refuted by any large cardinal axiom which can be formulated in the very general terms used to formulate such axioms. The Ultimate L Conjecture is an existential number theoretic statement and so it must be either true or false.

The research supported by this grant was focused on resolving the problem of the Ultimate L Conjecture, by either proving it or refuting it. Proving the Ultimate L Conjecture would provide the basis for arguing that the axiom, V = Ultimate L, is in fact true in the Universe of Sets, thus sharpening our conception of the Universe of Sets to a degree that renders Cohen's method powerless. On the other hand, refuting the Ultimate L Conjecture would force a complete revision of the program of dealing with the ramifications of Cohen's method of forcing while unfortunately very likely offering no insight into what that revison might be.

The primary outcome of the research supported by this grant was the development of a very detailed framework for proving the Ultimate L Conjecture. This framework isolates a somewhat lengthy but quite specific series of technical steps that must be taken. The project to complete this series of steps is now underway. This is the Ultimate L Project, supported by NSF grant 1664764. 

Research outcomes: Intellectual Merit

The discoveries made have greatly sharpened the conception of the Ultimate L Project and clarified the path forward. The intellectual merit of the research outcomes is that of advancing the understanding of Mathematical Infinity in what seems to be an important and fundamental direction.

Research outcomes: Broader Impacts

The research outcomes supported have been reported on by the PI in public lectures. These include the Paul Bernays Lectures (2016:ETH Zurich), the Asprey Lectures (2017:Vassar), the Kolchin Lecture (2018:Columbia),  and the Tarski Lectures (2018:Berkeley).The PI has given tutorials on aspects of the resaerch outcomes to beginning graduate students in five summer schools, 2014–2018, held at the Institute of Mathematical Science (National University of Singapore). This material was also presented by the PI in a series of four lectures at the 19th Midrasha Mathematicae Meeting held at the Hebrew University and hosted by the Institute for Advanced Studies. In summary, the broader impacts include graduate student training and public outreach.

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2018
Modified by: W. Hugh Woodin
